g.text: • supports the token exchange extension of OAuth2 as an STS service
• publishes its metadata on a URL /.well-known/oauth-authorization-server
• also acts as RqP's Identity Provider
• is registered at AS-RqP as a public or confidential client
• acts as a Relying Party in respect of the RqP's Identity Provider in order to obtain an access_token_with_user_claims
• is registered at AS-RO as a public or confidential client
• acts as a token forwarder that forwards tokens between the RS and STS, and between the STS and AS-RO
RO has set up the RS, registers the resources at the AS-RO and sets policies
1. Send HTTP request to the resource_uri with no access token
AS-RO generates the permission_ticket (a JWT with a random NONCE value in the sub claim)
and the resource_claims_token which is bound to the permission_ticket through the permission_ticket sub claim hash.
iss is the URI that identifies who issues the resource_claims_token
aud is the URI that identifies the requested resource
sub is the permission_ticket sub claim hash computed as Base64URL-Encode(SHA256(permission_ticket{sub})
exp, nbf are the standard JWT claims)
AS-RqP generates the identity_claims_token with these claims:
iss is the URI that identifies who issues the identity_claims_token
aud identifies the target service and it is the iss claim value extracted from resource_claims_token
sub identifies the principal by email address and was extracted from access_token_with_user_claims
exp, nbf are the standard JWT claims
act{sub} is the sub value extracted from resource_claims_token
6. Return the identity_claims_token in the access_token parameter,
AS-RO generates the access_token with these additional claims:
act{sub} is the sub value extracted from identity_claims_token
8. Return the access_token, optionally a refresh_token
10. Return HTTP response, typically with 200, 201 status code
Authorization assessment – evaluate the resource provenance / ownership
Authorization assessment – evaluate the RqP identity provenance / ownership
